title: What we learned from CPAC 2015
content:
NATIONAL HARBOR , Md . — Rand Paul won the straw poll . Jeb Bush got booed . Hillary Clinton , and the media , were bashed to no end .
Those were the headlines from this week ’ s Conservative Political Action Conference , a celebration for the GOP ’ s activist set and one of the first major Republican cattle calls of the 2016 presidential race . Beneath the surface , though , the confab revealed much about the contours of the emerging primary fight .
Bush showed he has a template for defending himself from attacks that he ’ s too moderate . Chris Christie ’ s slide continued . And Carly Fiorina positioned herself as Clinton ’ s main antagonist .
Scott Walker , meanwhile , is challenging Paul for conservative supremacy . Then there are two candidates who are about to make life difficult for their GOP rivals .
For Bush , the event had all the makings of a disaster . In recent weeks , prominent conservatives had criticized him . His support for comprehensive immigration reform and Common Core education standards — positions that are anathema to those gathered at the confab — had been rehashed . And his political pedigree had been railed against by tea partiers .
In the end , he beat expectations . In a 20-minute question-and-answer session with Fox News host Sean Hannity , Bush gave a forceful defense of his tenure as Florida governor . He spent much of his time offering detailed explanations for his support for in-state tuition and driver ’ s licenses for undocumented immigrants . He also defended his education positions , though he stressed that the federal government should play a limited role in school policies .
In each case , Bush , who ’ s quickly emerged as the establishment favorite , placed his more moderate positions in the context of what he said was a broader , more conservative , record . At the same time , he didn ’ t stake out positions too far to the right — something that could make his path to a general election win tougher .
When Hannity asked Bush about his ideological philosophy , he coolly answered that he ’ s a “ practicing , reform-minded conservative . ”
That ’ s not to say it was a totally smooth appearance for Bush . More than any other candidate , he came under fire from the audience . Some of them booed him , and in the hall outside a few activists protested . Just hours before his appearance , radio host Laura Ingraham took the stage to launch a broadside against the Florida Republican .
Bush is certain to face more resistance from conservatives in the months to come . But the former governor showed that he has a road map for putting his record in a more favorable light .
If the conference was any guide , Walker is making a serious run to be the favorite of CPAC ’ s libertarian-heavy crowd , which has long gravitated to Paul .
Like Paul , Walker received a raucous , standing ovation from a packed , sign-waving audience . ( “ Run , Scott , Run ! ” chanted Walker ’ s supporters . ) Like Paul , he had groups of young backers roaming the hallways of the Gaylord National Resort and passing out pamphlets . And like the Kentucky senator , he performed strongly in the straw poll , finishing just behind him in second place .
But Walker also had a few missteps . The Wisconsin governor stumbled when he seemed to compare fighting protestors in his home state to combating the Islamic State militant group . “ If I can take on 100,000 protesters , I can do the same across the world , ” he said . A spokeswoman later walked back the remark .
A few minutes later , Walker punted when asked his position on net neutrality ( “ I ’ m for freedom , ” was his response ) , and on the minimum wage . It ’ s not the first time he ’ s circumvented a contentious issue . Earlier this month , he refused to discuss his position on evolution . He ’ s also struggled to articulate a position on immigration .
Walker , who ’ s had less time in the national spotlight than some of his GOP foes , has catapulted to the top ranks of the field . But under the intense scrutiny of a presidential campaign , he ’ s showing a few blemishes .
If anyone came up short at CPAC , it was Christie .
The New Jersey governor , whose political fortunes have fallen in recent weeks , didn ’ t commit a gaffe or say anything outwardly embarrassing . But that didn ’ t make it any less hard to watch .
First , there were the questions from Ingraham , who came across as deeply skeptical in her cross examination . He ’ d had a “ rough few weeks , ” she told him . How would he survive ? Why was he so low in the polls , she wanted to know . And what about his temperament ? Was it really a good idea to tell a heckler to “ sit down and shut up , ” as he ’ d done last year ?
Then there Christie ’ s decision to go after Bush , who he described as the favorite of the “ elites in Washington. ” No other candidate jabbed the former governor so directly and , coming at such an early point in the race , it reflected a sense of desperation . In recent days , Christie has watched as some of his prominent former supporters have ditched him for Bush .
Finally , there was the audience — or lack thereof . Many of the seats were empty during Christie ’ s presentation .
Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Louisiana Gov . Bobby Jindal are positioning themselves as the skunks at the garden party — contenders who are relishing the prospect of going after their fellow Republicans .
Cruz devoted most of his speech to contrasting himself to his GOP rivals , who , he seemed to say , aren ’ t really all that conservative .
“ We all know in a campaign , every candidate comes up and tells you , ‘ I ’ m the most conservative guy that ’ s ever lived. ’ It ’ s just what they say , ” he said . “ But we have a way to tell the difference…I would encourage all the men and women gathered here today : Demand action , not talk . ”
Like Cruz , Jindal used his speech to accuse fellow Republicans of not being forceful enough in combating President Barack Obama ’ s plan to shield 5 million undocumented immigrants from deportation . “ It is time for our Republican leaders in Congress to grow a spine , ” he said . “ It ’ s time for them to do what we elected them to do . ”
Both seem to be calculating that the best way to reach the top tier of the GOP field is to climb over the backs of their rivals .
There ’ s no shortage of underdog Republican candidates , but most of them didn ’ t make much of a dent this week . Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum had the burden of following Paul , whose supporters departed the room in droves once Santorum took the stage . Physician Ben Carson delivered a little-noticed , early morning speech on the opening day of the conference . Former Ambassador John Bolton appeared before a mostly empty hall .
The former Hewlett Packard executive delivered a rousing speech in which she positioned herself as Clinton ’ s foil .
“ Like Mrs. Clinton , I too have traveled the globe . Unlike Mrs. Clinton , I know that flying is an activity , not an accomplishment , ” Fiorina said to roars of applause . “ Mrs . Clinton , name an accomplishment . ”
Fiorina , who waged an unsuccessful 2010 Senate bid in California , rocked the house again during the question-and-answer session when she suggested that her gender would ideally position her to compete with Clinton in the general election .
“ I will say this , ” she said . “ If Hillary Clinton had to face me on a debate stage at the very least she would have a hitch in her swing . ”
content_original:
NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. — Rand Paul won the straw poll. Jeb Bush got booed. Hillary Clinton, and the media, were bashed to no end.

Those were the headlines from this week’s Conservative Political Action Conference, a celebration for the GOP’s activist set and one of the first major Republican cattle calls of the 2016 presidential race. Beneath the surface, though, the confab revealed much about the contours of the emerging primary fight.

Story Continued Below

Bush showed he has a template for defending himself from attacks that he’s too moderate. Chris Christie’s slide continued. And Carly Fiorina positioned herself as Clinton’s main antagonist.

Scott Walker, meanwhile, is challenging Paul for conservative supremacy. Then there are two candidates who are about to make life difficult for their GOP rivals.

Here are POLITICO’s takeaways from CPAC:

Jeb survives

For Bush, the event had all the makings of a disaster. In recent weeks, prominent conservatives had criticized him. His support for comprehensive immigration reform and Common Core education standards — positions that are anathema to those gathered at the confab — had been rehashed. And his political pedigree had been railed against by tea partiers.

In the end, he beat expectations. In a 20-minute question-and-answer session with Fox News host Sean Hannity, Bush gave a forceful defense of his tenure as Florida governor. He spent much of his time offering detailed explanations for his support for in-state tuition and driver’s licenses for undocumented immigrants. He also defended his education positions, though he stressed that the federal government should play a limited role in school policies.

In each case, Bush, who’s quickly emerged as the establishment favorite, placed his more moderate positions in the context of what he said was a broader, more conservative, record. At the same time, he didn’t stake out positions too far to the right — something that could make his path to a general election win tougher.

When Hannity asked Bush about his ideological philosophy, he coolly answered that he’s a “practicing, reform-minded conservative.”

That’s not to say it was a totally smooth appearance for Bush. More than any other candidate, he came under fire from the audience. Some of them booed him, and in the hall outside a few activists protested. Just hours before his appearance, radio host Laura Ingraham took the stage to launch a broadside against the Florida Republican.

Bush is certain to face more resistance from conservatives in the months to come. But the former governor showed that he has a road map for putting his record in a more favorable light.

A conservative heartthrob, but one who stumbled

If the conference was any guide, Walker is making a serious run to be the favorite of CPAC’s libertarian-heavy crowd, which has long gravitated to Paul.

Like Paul, Walker received a raucous, standing ovation from a packed, sign-waving audience. (“Run, Scott, Run!” chanted Walker’s supporters.) Like Paul, he had groups of young backers roaming the hallways of the Gaylord National Resort and passing out pamphlets. And like the Kentucky senator, he performed strongly in the straw poll, finishing just behind him in second place.

But Walker also had a few missteps. The Wisconsin governor stumbled when he seemed to compare fighting protestors in his home state to combating the Islamic State militant group. “If I can take on 100,000 protesters, I can do the same across the world,” he said. A spokeswoman later walked back the remark.

A few minutes later, Walker punted when asked his position on net neutrality (“I’m for freedom,” was his response), and on the minimum wage. It’s not the first time he’s circumvented a contentious issue. Earlier this month, he refused to discuss his position on evolution. He’s also struggled to articulate a position on immigration.

Walker, who’s had less time in the national spotlight than some of his GOP foes, has catapulted to the top ranks of the field. But under the intense scrutiny of a presidential campaign, he’s showing a few blemishes.

Christie’s rough outing

If anyone came up short at CPAC, it was Christie.

The New Jersey governor, whose political fortunes have fallen in recent weeks, didn’t commit a gaffe or say anything outwardly embarrassing. But that didn’t make it any less hard to watch.

First, there were the questions from Ingraham, who came across as deeply skeptical in her cross examination. He’d had a “rough few weeks,” she told him. How would he survive? Why was he so low in the polls, she wanted to know. And what about his temperament? Was it really a good idea to tell a heckler to “sit down and shut up,” as he’d done last year?

Then there Christie’s decision to go after Bush, who he described as the favorite of the “elites in Washington.” No other candidate jabbed the former governor so directly and, coming at such an early point in the race, it reflected a sense of desperation. In recent days, Christie has watched as some of his prominent former supporters have ditched him for Bush.

Finally, there was the audience — or lack thereof. Many of the seats were empty during Christie’s presentation.

The agitators take a stand

Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal are positioning themselves as the skunks at the garden party — contenders who are relishing the prospect of going after their fellow Republicans.

Cruz devoted most of his speech to contrasting himself to his GOP rivals, who, he seemed to say, aren’t really all that conservative.

“We all know in a campaign, every candidate comes up and tells you, ‘I’m the most conservative guy that’s ever lived.’ It’s just what they say,” he said. “But we have a way to tell the difference…I would encourage all the men and women gathered here today: Demand action, not talk.”

Like Cruz, Jindal used his speech to accuse fellow Republicans of not being forceful enough in combating President Barack Obama’s plan to shield 5 million undocumented immigrants from deportation. “It is time for our Republican leaders in Congress to grow a spine,” he said. “It’s time for them to do what we elected them to do.”

Both seem to be calculating that the best way to reach the top tier of the GOP field is to climb over the backs of their rivals.

A dark horse emerges

There’s no shortage of underdog Republican candidates, but most of them didn’t make much of a dent this week. Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum had the burden of following Paul, whose supporters departed the room in droves once Santorum took the stage. Physician Ben Carson delivered a little-noticed, early morning speech on the opening day of the conference. Former Ambassador John Bolton appeared before a mostly empty hall.

But then there was Fiorina.

The former Hewlett Packard executive delivered a rousing speech in which she positioned herself as Clinton’s foil.

“Like Mrs. Clinton, I too have traveled the globe. Unlike Mrs. Clinton, I know that flying is an activity, not an accomplishment,” Fiorina said to roars of applause. “Mrs. Clinton, name an accomplishment.”

Fiorina, who waged an unsuccessful 2010 Senate bid in California, rocked the house again during the question-and-answer session when she suggested that her gender would ideally position her to compete with Clinton in the general election.

“I will say this,” she said. “If Hillary Clinton had to face me on a debate stage at the very least she would have a hitch in her swing.”
